Award.AwardTitle: Developing a New US - Spain Collaboration in Mygalomorph Spider Systematics and Conservation
Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this project is to catalyze a new set of collaborations and initiate a partnership with project PIs Jason Bond (Auburn University), Marshal Hedin (San Diego State University), and Brent Hendrixson (Millsaps College) and Miquel Arnedo, at the University of Barcelona in Spain. The project-planning trip to the Barcelona will bring together a group of investigators who have interests in the evolution, systematics, conservation, and taxonomy of mygalomorph spiders. The spider infraorder Mygalomorphae (trapdoor spiders, tarantulas, and their kin), are a biologically unique clade of early diverging spiders; many of its members are well known to non-arachnologists and include the world's largest (tarantulas), most venomous (Australian "funnel-web" spiders), and most long-lived spiders.

The planning trip will focus on reviewing the status of mygalomorph classification to identify "problem" lineages, bring together all of the genetic data currently available with the aim of developing a more comprehensive set of molecular markers, develop a workflow for identifying a set of morphological character ontologies and a means by which to share morphological data, and formulate a general paradigm for evaluating species boundaries and conservation status. The planning trip will culminate in a 10-day collecting trip in the Andalusia region of Spain. In addition to developing a number of tangible outcomes to include a set of molecular markers for broad scale analyses of spider phylogeny, significant broader impacts of the project will involve training students (undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral) in conceptual issues related to systematics, biodiversity conservation and evolutionary biology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Spiders (Order: Araneae) are the prototypical hyperdiverse arthropod group comprising > 45,000 described species placed among 3,933 genera and 114 families; by some estimates the group may comprise as many as 120,000 species. They are of substantial ecological importance: spiders are abundant, generalist predators that play dominant roles in almost every terrestrial ecosystem on the planet. The order represents an ancient group that has continued to diversify both taxonomically and in an ecological context since the Devonian (over 380 million years ago). Spiders are relatively easy to collect and identify, and one of few large arthropod orders that benefits from having a complete online taxonomic catalog with synonymies. In addition to remarkable ecology, diversity, and abundance, spiders are known for their extraordinary biomolecules like venoms and silks as well as their utility as models for behavioral and evolutionary studies.

 Despite considerable effort, progress in spider molecular systematics lags behind advances that have been made in other comparable arthropod groups and has hindered progress in resolving ordinal level classification problems and tests of important macroevolutionary hypotheses (e.g., venom, silk, and web spinning evolution). The majority of past higher, family-level, systematic treatments employed a scant number of genes that, by most accounts, would be considered inappropriate across such an ancient lineage of organisms. A recently published first phylogenomic analysis based on transcriptome data (Bond et al. 2014) clearly shows that relationships among spider families require major overhaul (e.g., the non-monophyly of orb weavers; also see preliminary data below); however, this study lacked sufficient taxon sampling to warrant changes in classification.

 The primary goal of this project was to develop a set of collaborations with European colleagues to advance spider systematics with a particular focus on spiders placed in the subgroup Mygalomorphae (the trapdoor spiders, tarantulas, and their relatives). As a consequence of project timing and new developments in next generation sequencing technologies, this collaboration expanded to include a multi-national team with members from the United States, Central America, Europe, and the Pacific (New Zealand). The newly constituted team of collaborators met at the 2014 European Arachnological Congress held in Torino, Italy where project participants presented their research and discussed the development of a large collaborative project aimed toward resolving major problems in spider phylogeny. To this end, members of the collaborative team submitted an NSF preproposal to the DEB Phylogenetic Systematics in January of 2015.

In addition to facilitating new collaborations and the development of a molecular marker toolkit for all spiders (using Anchored Enrichment probe approaches), this project provided a number of key opportunities for student training. Three graduate students presented their work at an international meeting and conducted field studies, of spiders, in Italy and Spain.  Students and a postodoctoral research associate (two of which are from backgrounds underrepresented in science) participated in data collection and project design.
